column5: displayName
column6: description

column5: App Service apps should only be accessible over HTTPS
column6: Use of HTTPS ensures server/service authentication and protects data in transit from network layer eavesdropping attacks.

column5: Function apps should only be accessible over HTTPS
column6: Use of HTTPS ensures server/service authentication and protects data in transit from network layer eavesdropping attacks.

column5: Automation account variables should be encrypted
column6: It is important to enable encryption of Automation account variable assets when storing sensitive data

column5: Only secure connections to your Azure Cache for Redis should be enabled
column6: Audit enabling of only connections via SSL to Azure Cache for Redis. Use of secure connections ensures authentication between the server and the service and protects data in transit from network layer attacks such as man-in-the-middle, eavesdropping, and session-hijacking

column5: Virtual machines should be migrated to new Azure Resource Manager resources
column6: Use new Azure Resource Manager for your virtual machines to provide security enhancements such as: stronger access control (RBAC), better auditing, Azure Resource Manager based deployment and governance, access to managed identities, access to key vault for secrets, Azure AD-based authentication and support for tags and resource groups for easier security management

column5: Audit usage of custom RBAC roles
column6: Audit built-in roles such as 'Owner, Contributer, Reader' instead of custom RBAC roles, which are error prone. Using custom roles is treated as an exception and requires a rigorous review and threat modeling

column5: Add system-assigned managed identity to enable Guest Configuration assignments on virtual machines with no identities
column6: This policy adds a system-assigned managed identity to virtual machines hosted in Azure that are supported by Guest Configuration but do not have any managed identities. A system-assigned managed identity is a prerequisite for all Guest Configuration assignments and must be added to machines before using any Guest Configuration policy definitions. For more information on Guest Configuration, visit https://aka.ms/gcpol.

column5: Add system-assigned managed identity to enable Guest Configuration assignments on VMs with a user-assigned identity
column6: This policy adds a system-assigned managed identity to virtual machines hosted in Azure that are supported by Guest Configuration and have at least one user-assigned identity but do not have a system-assigned managed identity. A system-assigned managed identity is a prerequisite for all Guest Configuration assignments and must be added to machines before using any Guest Configuration policy definitions. For more information on Guest Configuration, visit https://aka.ms/gcpol.

column5: Audit Windows machines that allow re-use of the passwords after the specified number of unique passwords
column6: Requires that prerequisites are deployed to the policy assignment scope. For details, visit https://aka.ms/gcpol. Machines are non-compliant if Windows machines that allow re-use of the passwords after the specified number of unique passwords. Default value for unique passwords is 24

column5: Audit Windows machines that do not have the maximum password age set to specified number of days
column6: Requires that prerequisites are deployed to the policy assignment scope. For details, visit https://aka.ms/gcpol. Machines are non-compliant if Windows machines that do not have the maximum password age set to specified number of days. Default value for maximum password age is 70 days

column5: Audit Windows machines that do not restrict the minimum password length to specified number of characters
column6: Requires that prerequisites are deployed to the policy assignment scope. For details, visit https://aka.ms/gcpol. Machines are non-compliant if Windows machines that do not restrict the minimum password length to specified number of characters. Default value for minimum password length is 14 characters

column5: Deploy the Windows Guest Configuration extension to enable Guest Configuration assignments on Windows VMs
column6: This policy deploys the Windows Guest Configuration extension to Windows virtual machines hosted in Azure that are supported by Guest Configuration. The Windows Guest Configuration extension is a prerequisite for all Windows Guest Configuration assignments and must be deployed to machines before using any Windows Guest Configuration policy definition. For more information on Guest Configuration, visit https://aka.ms/gcpol.

column5: Audit diagnostic setting for selected resource types
column6: Audit diagnostic setting for selected resource types. Be sure to select only resource types which support diagnostics settings.

column5: A maximum of 3 owners should be designated for your subscription
column6: It is recommended to designate up to 3 subscription owners in order to reduce the potential for breach by a compromised owner.

column5: A vulnerability assessment solution should be enabled on your virtual machines
column6: Audits virtual machines to detect whether they are running a supported vulnerability assessment solution. A core component of every cyber risk and security program is the identification and analysis of vulnerabilities. Azure Security Center's standard pricing tier includes vulnerability scanning for your virtual machines at no extra cost. Additionally, Security Center can automatically deploy this tool for you.

column5: Accounts with owner permissions on Azure resources should be MFA enabled
column6: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) should be enabled for all subscription accounts with owner permissions to prevent a breach of accounts or resources.

column5: Accounts with write permissions on Azure resources should be MFA enabled
column6: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) should be enabled for all subscription accounts with write privileges to prevent a breach of accounts or resources.

column5: All network ports should be restricted on network security groups associated to your virtual machine
column6: Azure Security Center has identified some of your network security groups' inbound rules to be too permissive. Inbound rules should not allow access from 'Any' or 'Internet' ranges. This can potentially enable attackers to target your resources.

column5: Blocked accounts with owner permissions on Azure resources should be removed
column6: Deprecated accounts with owner permissions should be removed from your subscription.  Deprecated accounts are accounts that have been blocked from signing in.

column5: Blocked accounts with read and write permissions on Azure resources should be removed
column6: Deprecated accounts should be removed from your subscriptions.  Deprecated accounts are accounts that have been blocked from signing in.

column5: Guest accounts with owner permissions on Azure resources should be removed
column6: External accounts with owner permissions should be removed from your subscription in order to prevent unmonitored access.

column5: Guest accounts with read permissions on Azure resources should be removed
column6: External accounts with read privileges should be removed from your subscription in order to prevent unmonitored access.

column5: Guest accounts with write permissions on Azure resources should be removed
column6: External accounts with write privileges should be removed from your subscription in order to prevent unmonitored access.

column5: Monitor missing Endpoint Protection in Azure Security Center
column6: Servers without an installed Endpoint Protection agent will be monitored by Azure Security Center as recommendations

column5: SQL databases should have vulnerability findings resolved
column6: Monitor vulnerability assessment scan results and recommendations for how to remediate database vulnerabilities.

column5: System updates should be installed on your machines
column6: Missing security system updates on your servers will be monitored by Azure Security Center as recommendations

column5: There should be more than one owner assigned to your subscription
column6: It is recommended to designate more than one subscription owner in order to have administrator access redundancy.

column5: Virtual machines should encrypt temp disks, caches, and data flows between Compute and Storage resources
column6: By default, a virtual machine's OS and data disks are encrypted-at-rest using platform-managed keys. Temp disks, data caches and data flowing between compute and storage aren't encrypted. Disregard this recommendation if: 1. using encryption-at-host, or 2. server-side encryption on Managed Disks meets your security requirements. Learn more in: Server-side encryption of Azure Disk Storage: https://aka.ms/disksse, Different disk encryption offerings: https://aka.ms/diskencryptioncomparison

column5: Vulnerabilities in security configuration on your machines should be remediated
column6: Servers which do not satisfy the configured baseline will be monitored by Azure Security Center as recommendations

column5: Service Fabric clusters should have the ClusterProtectionLevel property set to EncryptAndSign
column6: Service Fabric provides three levels of protection (None, Sign and EncryptAndSign) for node-to-node communication using a primary cluster certificate. Set the protection level to ensure that all node-to-node messages are encrypted and digitally signed

column5: An Azure Active Directory administrator should be provisioned for SQL servers
column6: Audit provisioning of an Azure Active Directory administrator for your SQL server to enable Azure AD authentication. Azure AD authentication enables simplified permission management and centralized identity management of database users and other Microsoft services

column5: Auditing on SQL server should be enabled
column6: Auditing on your SQL Server should be enabled to track database activities across all databases on the server and save them in an audit log.

column5: Transparent Data Encryption on SQL databases should be enabled
column6: Transparent data encryption should be enabled to protect data-at-rest and meet compliance requirements

column5: Secure transfer to storage accounts should be enabled
column6: Audit requirement of Secure transfer in your storage account. Secure transfer is an option that forces your storage account to accept requests only from secure connections (HTTPS). Use of HTTPS ensures authentication between the server and the service and protects data in transit from network layer attacks such as man-in-the-middle, eavesdropping, and session-hijacking

column5: Storage accounts should be migrated to new Azure Resource Manager resources
column6: Use new Azure Resource Manager for your storage accounts to provide security enhancements such as: stronger access control (RBAC), better auditing, Azure Resource Manager based deployment and governance, access to managed identities, access to key vault for secrets, Azure AD-based authentication and support for tags and resource groups for easier security management

column5: Storage accounts should restrict network access
column6: Network access to storage accounts should be restricted. Configure network rules so only applications from allowed networks can access the storage account. To allow connections from specific internet or on-premises clients, access can be granted to traffic from specific Azure virtual networks or to public internet IP address ranges
